answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
All four cities I have worked for have run some concessions,but in most cases leased a city owned property to a grocery and other retail or office use on a competitive RFP process.  This allowed the cities to get the uses it wanted and needed with the obligations to operate set criteria with an experienced operator.  I find that city staffs and electeds are focused on so many other public issues and services that running retail activities do not get the focus and attention they need to be successful.  I have operated as much as 400,000 square feet of city owned retail and office space in one city.

answers.author: Harry Staven
answers.text:
Steve,
Municipality-owned and operated businesses are rather common here in Alaska.  Most small communities operate municipal washeterias/saunas, bingo/pull tab and liquor store.  There are some who even operate the grocery store.  St. Mary's operates a gravel pit and rents out its equipment for projects around the community.  
I can be reached at 907-438-2515 or via email at this address.
Harry A. Staven, St. Mary's, AK
